We always pass host=None to _engine_topic() which means that we always
construct a topic using CONF.engine_topic and CONF.host.

constructor, we never need to explicitly pass it.

We can safely remove the _engine_topic() method and the passing of an
explicit topic to RpcProxy methods and replace it with constructing the
correct topic at construction time, without causing any functional
changes.

CONF.

subject: Block Device Mapping refactoring - DB & API layer
commit_message:
Block Device Mapping refactoring - DB & API layer

This patch is the first part of refactoring of how nova internally
handles block device mappings for instance.

This patch introducese the following high level changes:

* Migrates the database and adds new columns to the BlockDeviceMapping
table
* Introduces the API extension to handle the new data format that can be
passed to Nova and still be able to handle the old data model, and API
* Introduces more solid block device validation in the API layer.
* Refactors tests to be aware of the new data structure
* Introduces some common routines for dealing with block device mappings

The substantial size of the patch is due to the fact that block devices
are used heavily throughout Nova and changing the data layout resulting
in the need to tweak a lot of differents parts of the codebase. Going
forward there will be more work put into unifying the programming
interface through which nova code will deal with block devices so that
future changes can be less invasive.

More details on the new data model and the future interfaces are layed
out in the following wiki page:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/BlockDeviceConfig

blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

subject: Refactored lists of nodes to contact for requests
commit_message:
Refactored lists of nodes to contact for requests

Extensive refactor here to consolidate what nodes are contacted for
any request. This consolidation means reads will contact the same set
of nodes that writes would, giving a very good chance that
read-your-write behavior will succeed. This also means that writes
will not necessarily try all nodes in the cluster as it would
previously, which really wasn't desirable anyway. (If you really want
that, you can set request_node_count to a really big number, but
understand that also means reads will contact every node looking for
something that might not exist.)

* Added a request_node_count proxy-server conf value that allows
  control of how many nodes are contacted for a normal request.

In proxy.controllers.base.Controller:

* Got rid of error_increment since it was only used in one spot by
  another method and just served to confuse.

* Made error_occurred also log the device name.

* Made error_limit require an error message and also documented a bit
  better.

* Changed iter_nodes to just take a ring and a partition and yield
  all the nodes itself so it could control the number of nodes used
  in a given request. Also happens to consolidate where sort_nodes is
  called.

* Updated account_info and container_info to use all nodes from
  iter_nodes and to call error_occurred appropriately.

* Updated GETorHEAD_base to not track attempts on its own and just
  stop when iter_nodes tells it to stop. Also, it doesn't take the
  nodes to contact anymore; instead it takes the ring and gets the
  nodes from iter_nodes itself.

Elsewhere:

* Ring now has a get_part method.

commit_message:
RHEL6 core support

 - Allow RHEL6 as a valid target for installation

 - Qpid package name is different in RHEL6 to Fedora

 - Add some post-prereq actions:
  * pre-install dbus to avoid the service not having ever been started
  * a workaround for a hgtools/setuptools bug
  * install pycrypto and lxml as pip dependencies to ensure overrding
    of local versions
  * fix-up a dependency issue with prettytable by pre-installing

 - Split out the RHEL6 rpms into a separate list.  Various changes
   here to the base Fedora versions to not specify RHEL6 packages that
   are too old or conflict

 - The RHEL6 version of pip doesn't have support for mirrors, so skip
   asking for them.

 - Separate F18 polkit config and ensure it's written out for RHEL6,
   or you get authentication errors with libvirt

 - RHEL6 has no nodejs in main packages or in EPEL.  The easiest way

subject: Replace metadata joins with another query
commit_message:
Replace metadata joins with another query

Right now, we always join metadata and system_metadata when we query for
instances. This inflates the number of rows returned by a factor of ten
at a minimum, and over 30 in some situations. This patch avoids the
direct join of these tables in favor of a "manual join" which performs
additional queries to fill the needed data. Latency may be increased,
but with the gain of a potentially significant amount of reduction in
data transfer.

This also provides the ability for the queries which utilize it to
selectively decide whether either or both of these additional fills are
performed, paving the way for future high-level optimizations.

Some version of NEC ProgrammableFlow OpenFlow controller, one of

subject: Make "shared" filter more compatible with diff DBs
commit_message:
Make "shared" filter more compatible with diff DBs

For the type BOOLEAN, in sqlalchemy,
it's mapped to BOOLEAN type if the backend database supports it,
otherwise, it's mapped to one of the Integer types, like SMALLINT,
and restrict the values to 1(True) and 0(False).

query_filter = (... | model.shared))
The above filter will generate a SQL where clause like:
where ... OR xxx.shared

This is not supported in databases which don't support BOOLEAN type.
Change it as below to make it more compatible:
query_filter = (... | model.shared == True))

It will generate a SQL where clause as below:
where ... OR xxx.shared = ?

In Python, True == 1, so this change is compatible
with both databases supporting BOOLEAN and those not supporting it.

Fix bug 1161195

The minimum way to fix this bug is to specify OFC network ID from Quantum.

Since V3 of PFC does not return network/port ID in the response when ID is
